Generation I.Red: Its hard shell repels any kind of attack. It is vulnerable only when its shell is open.
Generation I.Green: (This entry was originally untranslated in English until it was reused in Pokémon FireRed .)
Generation I.Blue: Its hard shell repels any kind of attack. It is vulnerable only when its shell is open.
Generation I.Yellow: The shell can withstand any attack. However, when it is open, the tender body is exposed.
Generation I.Stadium: Its shell is harder than diamond. It hides in sand on the sea floor and catches prey with its soft tongue.

Generation II.Gold: It swims facing backward by opening and closing its two-piece shell. It is surprisingly fast.
Generation II.Silver: Grains of sand trapped in its shells mix with its body fluids to form beautiful pearls.
Generation II.Crystal: Clamping on to an opponent reveals its vulnerable parts, so it uses this move only as a last resort.
Generation II.Stadium 2: It swims facing backward by opening and closing its two-piece shell. It is surprisingly fast. (Pokémon Red, Silver, or Crystal inserted) Grains of sand trapped in its shells mix with its body fluids to form beautiful pearls. (Pokémon Blue, Gold, or Yellow inserted)

Generation III.Ruby: At night, this Pok é mon uses its broad tongue to burrow a hole in the seafloor sand and then sleep in it. While it is sleeping, Shellder closes its shell, but leaves its tongue hanging out.
Generation III.Sapphire: At night, this Pok é mon uses its broad tongue to burrow a hole in the seafloor sand and then sleep in it. While it is sleeping, Shellder closes its shell, but leaves its tongue hanging out.
Generation III.Emerald: At night, it burrows a hole in the seafloor with its broad tongue to make a place to sleep. While asleep, it closes its shell, but leaves its tongue hanging out.
Generation III.FireRed: It is encased in a shell that is harder than diamond. Inside, however, it is surprisingly tender.
Generation III.LeafGreen: Its hard shell repels any kind of attack. It is vulnerable only when its shell is open.

Generation IV.Diamond: It swims backward by opening and closing its two shells. Its large tongue is always kept hanging out.
Generation IV.Pearl: It swims backward by opening and closing its two shells. Its large tongue is always kept hanging out.
Generation IV.Platinum: It swims backward by opening and closing its two shells. Its large tongue is always kept hanging out.
Generation IV.HeartGold: It swims facing backward by opening and closing its two-piece shell. It is surprisingly fast.
Generation IV.SoulSilver: Grains of sand trapped in its shells mix with its body fluids to form beautiful pearls.

Generation V.Black: It swims backward by opening and closing its two shells. Its large tongue is always kept hanging out.
Generation V.White: It swims backward by opening and closing its two shells. Its large tongue is always kept hanging out.
Generation V.Black 2: It swims backward by opening and closing its two shells. Its large tongue is always kept hanging out.
Generation V.White 2: It swims backward by opening and closing its two shells. Its large tongue is always kept hanging out.

Generation VI.X: Its hard shell repels any kind of attack. It is vulnerable only when its shell is open.
Generation VI.Y: Clamping on to an opponent reveals its vulnerable parts, so it uses this move only as a last resort.
Generation VI.Omega Ruby: At night, this Pokémon uses its broad tongue to burrow a hole in the seafloor sand and then sleep in it. While it is sleeping, Shellder closes its shell, but leaves its tongue hanging out.
Generation VI.Alpha Sapphire: At night, this Pokémon uses its broad tongue to burrow a hole in the seafloor sand and then sleep in it. While it is sleeping, Shellder closes its shell, but leaves its tongue hanging out.

Generation VII.Sun: The hardness of its shell surpasses the hardness of a diamond. In days gone by, people used the shells to make shields.
Generation VII.Moon: This Pokémon's tongue is always hanging out. It uses its tongue with great dexterity to dig up sand from the seabed in its search for food.
Generation VII.Ultra Sun: The sand that accumulates inside its shell eventually becomes a pearl. But the pearl gets in the way, so it spits it out and discards it.
Generation VII.Ultra Moon: Even when its shell is closed, its tongue still hangs out. If you give its tongue a good yank, the shock will cause Shellder to open its shell.
Generation VII.Let's Go Pikachu: The shell can withstand any attack. However, when it is open, the tender body is exposed.
Generation VII.Let's Go Eevee: The shell can withstand any attack. However, when it is open, the tender body is exposed.

Generation VIII.Sword: It swims facing backward by opening and closing its two-piece shell. It is surprisingly fast.
Generation VIII.Shield: Its hard shell repels any kind of attack. It is vulnerable only when its shell is open.
Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: It swims backward by opening and closing its two shells. Its large tongue is always kept hanging out.
Generation VIII.Shining Pearl: It swims backward by opening and closing its two shells. Its large tongue is always kept hanging out.

Generation IX.Scarlet: It is encased in a shell that is harder than diamond. Inside, however, it is surprisingly tender.
Generation IX.Violet: Clamping on to an opponent reveals its vulnerable parts, so it uses this move only as a last resort.
